characters: CAMERA FOLLOWS HIM INTO THE ROOM. THE TV
ANN KAYE V. ST. CATHERINE LABOURE HOSPITAL ET AL."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A working-class funeral in progress. THIRTY PEOPLE and an inexpensive bier SEEN from the back of the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A MAN's back FILLS the SCREEN. He is dressed in a black s his hands are clasped behind him. ANOTHER MAN stands next him. The Second Man reaches behind the First Man's back a puts a discreetly folded ten-dollar bill into his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These Two Men from the front. Both somber, in their early fifties. They begin to walk down the aisle of the funeral parlor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WIDOW. A woman in her late fifties sitting by the bie receiving condolences. The Two Men approach her. The Firs Man (the recipient of the money) speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dee, this is Frank Galvin -- a  very good friend of ours, and a very  fine attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shame about your husband,  Mrs. Dee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Widow nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew him vaguely through the Lodge.  He was a wonderful man. (shakes head in  sympathy) It was a crime what happened to him.  A crime. If there's anything that I  could do to help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GALVIN removes a business card from his jacket pocket and hands it to her as if he were giving her money. (i.e., "T it. Really. I want you to have it..." She takes the card. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thoughtfully realizes  he is usurping her  time) Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes her hand and moves on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin sitting in the deserted coffee shop in his raincoa Reading a section of the paper. He picks up his teacup,  drinks. Lowers it to the table.

dialogues.speaker: INSERT
dialogues.text: Galvin twists tea bag around a spoon to extract last drop of tea. His hand moves to his felt pen lying on the table He moves his hand to the paper, open at the obituary sect We SEE several names crossed out. He circles one funeral  listing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin sitting, raises cup of tea to his lips. Looks arou deserted coffee shop. Sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin outside a second funeral home. WORKING-CLASS PEOPL entering, Galvin enters the home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, coming down the aisle toward the front, shrugging himself out of his overcoat, he approaches the BEREAVED W sitting by the front of the home, he extracts his card fr his pocket, starts to speak. He is stopped by the WIDOW'S SON, a hefty man in his mid-forties, who interjects himse between Galvin and the widow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (of the card) What is that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I was a friend of your fa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never knew my father. (hits card out of  Galvin's hand) You get out of here, who the hell do  you think you are...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FUNERAL MANAGER hurries down the aisle, and starts  extricating Galvin from the commotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Funeral Manager) I'm talking to this man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mrs. Cleary...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is manhandling Galvin toward the back of the funeral  parlor. The Son calls after him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Funeral Manager and Galvin standing in the cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you coming back here.  Ever. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just talking to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are bereaved people in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Funeral Manager gives Galvin a small shove, and goes  back to his post at the door, greeting the entering mourn "Good evening..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, the ground cut out from under him. Standing watch the mourners enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin walking down a residential street. He has been wal a while in the cold, snowy night. He stops for a stopligh at a corner, waits for the light although there is no tra Lights a cigarette. The light changes. He looks both ways and irresolutely starts across the street. He stops. He c his watch. He sighs, and starts back in the opposite  direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin holding forth at the bar of a seedy drinking-man's establishment, THREE DRINKERS, acquaintances, standing ar him, appreciative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pat says, 'Mike... there's a new  bar, you go in, for a half a buck  you get a beer, a free lunch, and  then take you in the back room and  they get you laid.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender, JIMMY, comes up to Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another, Frank...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures to include  group) ...everybody. Mike says, 'Pat, you  mean to tell me for a buck you get a  free lunch and a beer, and then you  go in the back and get laid?' 'That's  correct.' Mike says, 'Pat. Have you  been in this bar ?' Pat says, 'No,  but my sister has...' (gestures to Jimmy) Everyone. Buy yourself one too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seedy, disorganized small office, Galvin in shirt-sle opening a file cabinet. He takes out an armload of files, carries them to a wastebasket and throws them in. He sits his desk, as if exhausted by his effort, pours from a whi bottle into a large water glass, downs the glass. He has been drinking for some time. He starts stumbling b to the file cabinet. On the way his eye is caught by his  degrees hanging on the wall. He stumbles to them, picks t up and walks over to the wastebasket and throws them in. goes back to the file cabinet, the phone starts ringing.  Galvin lets it ring, continues emptying the files into th wastebasket, tearing some of them up as he does so. He repeats softly to himself, as a litany, "It doesn't ma a bit of difference, it doesn't make a bit of difference. He starts back to the desk for the bottle, knocks the sti ringing phone off the desk. He pours himself a drink. As he downs it we hear -- softly -- from the phone on the floor: a MAN'S VOICE. "Frank. Frank. Frank. Goddamnit. Ar you there...? Frank..." Galvin pays no attention. Drinks his drink and gazes at the wall -- now empty of  degrees. ANGLE - P.O.V. The empty wall. Galvin's P.O.V. The telephone heard Voice Over insisting, "Frank..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICKEY MORRISSEY, a man in his late sixties, dressed in s and overcoat, looking worried, unlocks the door to the da anteroom. Looks around. Sees something in the next room. ANGLE - P.O.V. Galvin asleep on his couch, clothed as before. Covered in his overcoat, the bottle and glass next to the couch on t floor, the sound of the phone off the hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey walks into the office. Stands looking at Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (harshly) Get up. (beat, more harshly) Get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin wakes up. Looks around. Swings his legs over the c Drinks from the glass. Vacantly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mickey...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you think you're  doing...? (surveys the wrecked  office) What's going on here...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you. I got a call today from  Sally Doneghy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...now who is that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You're 'sposed to be in court in  ten days and she's telling me you  haven't even met with them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Doneghy, now who is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One lousy letter eighteen months  ago... I try to throw a fuckin' case  your way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...hey, I don't need your charity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I get these people to trust you --  they're coming here tomorrow by the  way -- I get this expert doctor to  talk to you. I'm doing all your  fuckin' legwork -- and it's eighteen  months. You're 'sposed to be in court.  I bet you haven't even seen the file.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin pours himself a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what are you, my nanny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey walks to him, knocks the drink out of his hand and slaps him several times in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me. Listen to me... listen  to me, Frank, 'cause I'm done fuckin'  with you. I can't do it any more.  Look around you: You think that you're  going to change? What's going to  change it? You think it's going to  be different next month? It's going  to be the same. And I have to stop.  This is it. I got you a good case,  it's a moneymaker. You do it right  and it will take care of you. But  I'm through. I'm sorry, Frank, this  is the end. (beat) Life is too short, and I'm too old. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey walks out of the office. Slams the door. Beat. Galvin looks around the office. Goes to his sofa. Sits,  reaches to side table.

dialogues.speaker: INSERT
dialogues.text: The side table, a pack of Luckies. Galvin taking one, his hand shaking a little. Also on side table a pile of chang containing a small rosary and a wedding ring.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The carriage of a typewriter. A sheet of paper. Its lette reads "Frank P. Galvin. Attorney at Law, 124 State Street Boston, Mass. 02981. Cable FRAGAL." Someone is typing, "S I had to go out. Back at 10. Judge Geary called. Are you  available for lunch Wednesday University Club?" A hand ta a paper from carriage and puts it on desk. Takes a pen an signs, "Claire."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin in the anteroom, dressed in his suit, unshaved, ha just signed the paper. He takes a piece of Scotch tape fr the dispenser on the desk, picks up a file folder from th coffee table. It is torn in several places and rudely Sco taped.

dialogues.speaker: P.O.V.
dialogues.text: The file headed Deborah Ann Kaye v. St. Catherine Laboure Hospital et. al.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin surveys the anteroom, opens door to corridor, Scot tapes the note he has just typewritten to the outside of door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark paneling, clean, simple. A drinkers' bar. OLD BARTEN and THREE CUSTOMERS spaced widely, Galvin in his overcoat downing a shot, the file open before him. He is reading. He checks his watch, scoops the file together under his a throws a dollar on the bar, and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin walking tentatively down the corridor of a very ru nursing home. He receives suspicious looks from the  Attendants. He is checking numbers on the doors against a notation in the file. He finds the correct door and enter

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the ward from the inside. Galvin opening the  door to the dark ward, backlit, tentative, a little unste from his drinking. He puts his back against the door, put down file and briefcase, extracts a small cheap Polaroid  camera from the briefcase, readies it to shoot, picks up paraphernalia, and starts off down the ward. As he walks  down the ward he checks the file hung at the foot of each bed. Galvin stops at the foot of one bed and reads the ch ANGLE - P.O.V. The chart held by Galvin. DEBORAH ANN KAYE, various medic notations. He lowers the chart and we SEE in the bed beyo it a shriveled, tiny form stuck with needles and tubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin replaces the chart, puts his file, briefcase, etc. the foot of the bed, takes a flash photo of the figure in the bed. Takes another one. Puts down camera, sits on the end of the bed gazing at the unseen form. He lights a  cigarette, and sits looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLY DONEGHY. A mousy woman in her forties is standing b door on which is written, "Frank P. Galvin. Attorney at L

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... Mrs. Doneghy? I'm Frank  Galvin... why didn't you go in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished) It's locked?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sally Doneghy points to the note on the door. Galvin take it from the door. Reads. "Back at 10, Judge Geary. Lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm terribly sorry... I hope we didn't  put you out. Won't you come in...? (motions Sally into  inner office, gestures  with note) I'd offer you some coffee, but it  looks like my girl just went out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin is perched at his secretary's desk. Sally Doneghy  across from him by the coffee table listening intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not a good case. It's a very  good case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A healthy young woman goes into the  hospital to deliver her third child,  she's given the wrong anesthetic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we, we love her, Dick and me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sure you do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what can we do? She don't know  who's visiting her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I know. I went...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You saw her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how beautiful she was? (beat) Her husband left her, and he took  her kids... They, they, they'd let  you die in there. They don't care.  Nobody cares. The Patriot Home, the  Chronic Care... in Arlington...?  They'd take her in. Perpetual care.  They'd take her. Fifty thousand  dollars they want. An endowment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...fifty thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to leave her. Dick...  the, the... and Father Laughlin, he  said that it was God's will...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My doctor told me that I got to move  out West... that's when we filed in  court. We didn't want to sue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...But Dick, he's looking for two  years in Tucson... and they called  him up and said to come out. He's a  good man. He's only trying to do  what's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door to the corridor opens and DICK DONEGHY, a workin in his forties, comes into the room. Sally and Galvin sta

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Donegy and Galvin shake hands uncomfortably. He motions t two to sit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please sit down. I told your wife.  I'm sorry that we have to meet out  here. I've got a case coming in two  days in the Superior Court and my  office is a mess of papers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was telling your wife, we have a  very good case here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saw her at the Northern Care...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I have inquiries out to  doctors, experts in the field...  there is, of course, a problem getting  a doctor to testify that another  doctor's negligent...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the Archdiocese called up, they  said who was our attorney, 'cause  the case is coming to trial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt we'll have to go to trial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we told them we didn't want it to  come out this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I completely understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just can't do it anymore. (beat) This is our chance to get away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to see you get that chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this going to cost?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's completely done on a contingency  basis. That means whatever the  settlement is I retain one-third...  that is, of course, the usual  arrangement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellowed newspaper clipping, a very lovely, patrician wom in her twenties smiling at a well-turned-out Galvin aroun thirty. Headline: "Patricia Harrington to Wed."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Frank Galvin. B.U. Law,  class of 'fifty-two. Second in his  class. Editor of the Law Review.  Worked with Mickey Morrissey twelve  years. Criminal Law and Personal  Injury...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand turns a page and reveals a second clipping: "Bosto Lawyer Held in Jury Tampering Case," with a picture of a  very confused Galvin at around forty-five being led to ja

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Married Patricia Harrington, nineteen  sixty...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small, sumptuously appointed Italianate office. French windows, a fire in the grate, a view of Boston Com JOSEPH ALITO, a slender, elegant man in his forties dress in a very expensive suit, reading from his notes, news  clippings, etc., which are held in a leather folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Joined Stearns, Harrington, Pierce  nineteen sixty as a full partner.  Resigned the firm nineteen sixt-ynine  over the Lillibridge case...' Do  you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alito, strolling as he reads, moves toward the windows wi his file TO REVEAL BISHOP BROPHY, a self-contained man in his early sixties, sitting on a leather couch, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He was accused of jury tampering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Accused. Not indicted. He resigned  the firm. Divorced nineteen seventy.  Galvin worked with Michael Morrissey  until Morrissey retired in 'seventy- eight. Since then he's been on his  own. Four cases before the Circuit  Court. He lost them all. He drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four cases in three years...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man's an ambulance chaser...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...tell me about this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a nuisance suit. He's looking  for small change. He's asking for  six hundred thousand and betting we  don't want to go to court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- we don't want this case in  court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither does he. That's where he  loses. This man's scared to death to  go to court. We only have to call  his bluff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to settle this thing and be  done with it. I don't want the  Archdiocese exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Absolutely, and we're going to  see that it is not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what I want to do is stop it here.  I'm going to make him an offer. I  want to do it myself. I want it to  come from me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. But let's keep the price  down. I've called Ed Concannon. He  recommends that we continue to respond  as if we're going to trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop nods, meaning, "You are dismissed." As an  afterthought:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we were to go to trial, would we  win the case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, of course, it's always  dangerous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know that answer. If we went to  trial would we win?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in an "of course"  tone) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alito, preparing to leave, reaches to the Bishop's desk,  where he has laid his leather folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clipping in the folder, confused Galvin being led int jail, "Boston Lawyer Held in Jury Tampering Case." Alito' hand snaps the folder shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man's arms full of textbooks. Prominently displayed: "Methodology and Practice in Anesthesiology." The man sto fumbles for a key in his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, in his overcoat, arms full of books, reading from textbook and trying to unlock his office door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin entering. CLAIRE PAVONE, a woman in her fifties, a the secretary's desk, hanging up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to phone) Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin looks up at her in surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey told me to come back to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin nods, proceeds into his office, reading from the  textbook. Claire follows him into the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...here's your mail, call Mrs.  Doneghy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yes. Get her on the phone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that was a Dr. David Gruber's  office...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting down books) Gruber...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey told him to call. (reading from notes) 'He's some very hotshot surgeon at  Mass. Commonwealth. He wants to meet  with you at seven tonight re testimony  in the case of Deborah Ann Kaye. You  meet him at the hospital.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hands him typed memo slip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) ...he wants to testify...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It looks that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what that would mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To get somebody from a Boston hospital  to say he'll testify?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a Mrs. Doneghy called... I told  you that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Phone rings. Claire moves to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted) This is going to drive the ante up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Frank Galvin's... who's calling  please? Bishop Brophy's office...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures to Galvin, "Do you want to talk to them?" Ga gestures back, "No. I'm not in..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, he's not in... may I take  a mess... tomorrow when, two  o'clock... I'll check my book...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks to Galvin, who nods, "yes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Mr. Galvin's clear at that  time... the Bishop's office, tomorrow,  the fifth at two p.m. Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the call that I'm waiting  for.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want to settle. (beat) It means a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does that mean I'm back for awhile?

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Man's wrist. WWII GI watch reads: 6:56.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin in overcoat standing outside door marked "Doctors  Only" in bustling hospital corridor. He glances at memo s in his hand. He opens door. CAMERA FOLLOWS him onto:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carpeted, small, comfortable, lined in lockers. A DOCTOR, the phone in greens, smoking a cigarette, talking on the  phone softly, a couple of DOCTORS sitting, drinking coffe chatting. Galvin, a trifle nervous, to Doctor ON PHONE:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gruber...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctor on the phone gestures behind him to a thirty-i MAN in blue jeans smoking a cigar, changing at his locker Galvin walks over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gruber...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning) Yes? Galvin, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He checks his watch, continues changing into suede jacket checks next appointment on a leather appointment book, lo the locker, pockets key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I appreciate -- a man as busy as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's perfectly all right. I'm kind  of rushed. Do you mind if we walk  while we talk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gruber, Galvin following, talk while exiting locker room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read the hospital report on your  client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Deborah Ann Kaye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Deborah Ann Kaye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk hurriedly through a hospital corridor, to an EX door and down concrete stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They called, they're going to settle,  what I want to do is build up as  much...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Who called?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Archdiocese called, they want to  settle... her estate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and you're going to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised, of course) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to settle out of court?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gruber stops at the bottom of the stairs, beside an exit the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (it's a meaningless  question to him, as  if to a child) Uh... in the, well, in the interests  of her family... you, Dr. Gruber,  you know, you can never tell what a  jury is going to do. St. Catherine's  a very well thought of institution.  Her doctors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances at watch,  impatient) Her doctors killed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat) I'm sorry...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her doctors murdered her. They gave  her the wrong anesthetic and they  put her in the hospital for life. (a beat) Her doctors murdered her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know who her doctors were?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read the file. Yeah. Marx and  Towler. I know who they were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The most respected...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Whose side are you arguing...? I  thought that you wanted to do  something. I don't have any interest  in the woman's 'estate' -- No offense,  but we all know where the money's  going to... I have an interest in  the Hospital; and I don't want those  bozos working in the same shop as  me. They gave her the wrong  anesthetic. They turned the girl  into a vegetable. They killed her  and they killed her kid. You caught  'em. Now: how many others did they  kill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Gruber discards end of a cigar. Takes a leather c from his suede jacket, extracts a new cigar. Offers one t Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want a cigar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin takes one absently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hospital is owned by the  Archdioceses of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they going to do? Not invite  me to their Birthday party...? (checks watch) Look, I gotta go. I have to be in  Cambridge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, excited, is trying to light the cigar. His hand s badly. He has forgotten to bite off the end. He bites it, lights the cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, when can we meet again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like to get a deposition..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I'll meet you here. Tuesday  night... I gotta go. You going my  way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gruber opens door and walks out into the cold, into the  parking lot, followed by Galvin, who is lighting his ciga

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to... we... we have to keep  you under wraps. Please don't, don't  discuss...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the case with anyone. And I'll  meet you Tuesday, and we'll go over  your testimony...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop before a 1950s very beautiful small Mercedes Se Gruber opens the door, gets into the plush red leather  interior, starts car, leaves door open, still talking to  Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Seven o'clock. Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin scribbles information in his appointment book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that's perfectly all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Uh, why, why are you doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks a second) To do right. Isn't that why you're  doing it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin is at the bar, smiling to himself. His drink is be refilled. To BARTENDER:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to buy you a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Franky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin looks around. A very attractive self-possessed YOU WOMAN is sitting in the crook of the bar across from him; she is intently perusing the newspaper and circling items with a felt pen. Galvin speaks to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd like an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Settle for a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gestures at her own full glass in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a very good day today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat, smiles, downs  drink, gets up off  the stool, sincerely) I'm glad you did. Thank you. Good  night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're very welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He watches her as she leaves the bar. He turns back to hi drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, well, well. Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) It's a long road that has no turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's for sure, Frank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shoddy one-and-a-half room bachelor apartment. Galvin,  beer and cigarettes on the table beside him. He is sittin on an armchair in the bedroom. A yellow legal pad in his  lap. He is talking on the phone softly, soothingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to the Archdiocese tomorrow  at two. I know you don't. I know you  don't... no, you're just following  your life. You have a life too...  you have to move out West. It doesn't  help you to stay here. Well... I'm  sure she knows you care for her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His attention wanders to the legal pad in his lap. ANGLE - P.O.V. The legal pad. Spread on it a couple of Polaroids of Debo Ann in the nursing home. Below them, written on the pad,  large, "Dr. David Gruber. Ass't. Chief Anesthesiology, Ma Commonwealth. 'They killed her. And they killed her kid - Her doctors murdered her.'" The following figures are written on the pad: $150,000.00 written very large, circled, crossed out. $250,000.00  similarly circled and crossed out. $225,000.00 circled ma times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over; on phone) Well. Well. Well. Finally we're none  of us protected... we... we just  have to go on. To seek help where we  can... and go on... I know that you  love her... I know you're acting out  of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) As soon as I know... you give him my  respects too. Not at all. Not at  all... Good night. (beat) Well, bless you, too. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up phone, sighs. Lights a cigarette. Rotates his neck to loosen it up. Reaches to the table next to his be for the bottle to pour a drink.

dialogues.speaker: INSERT
dialogues.text: His hand reaching for the bottle. On the table the photo a very beautiful blonde woman in a silver frame. She is t same woman we saw earlier in the news clip. She is on the deck of a sailboat, laughing. A pile of change on the tab a money clip, a rosary, and the wedding ring in the pile change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin looking at the photo in the silver frame next to h bed. He sighs deeply. Beat. Reaches up to the lamp above head and turns it off. He sits stiffly in the dark a mome then lets his head fall back to the chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, spruced up a bit, sitting on a bed, his briefcase his lap. Gazing at the unseen Deborah Ann Kaye in the dar ward. Silent. Beat. He looks in his briefcase, takes out file.

dialogues.speaker: P.O.V.
dialogues.text: The file, labeled Deborah Ann Kaye. Galvin extracting the photo of the young mother romping with her two children; takes the yellow legal pad from his briefcase and puts it top of the picture (the figures crossed out; "Her doctors murdered her," etc.). We hear the door to the ward open and TWO IRISH WOMEN  gossiping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy, I said, don't you go in your  pocket if there's nothing there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and what did he say...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spies Galvin, her  tone changes) ...Sir, you aren't allowed to be in  here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin sitting on the bed looking at Deborah Ann. He look up to the speaker. A slovenly Irish Nurse, who has come i the room and is standing by him. The other Nurse is frame in the doorway. Galvin is lost in thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't be in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if remembering  something, simply) I'm her attorney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop from the waist up, sitting behind his beautifu desk. Compassionately:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a question of continuing values.  St. Catherine's -- to do the good  that she must do in the community  has to maintain the position that  she holds in the community. So we  have a question of balance. On the  one hand, the reputation, and, so,  the effectiveness of our hospital,  and two of her important doctors --  and, on the other hand, the rights  of your client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin seated across from the Bishop. A YOUNG PRIEST seat discreetly, attentively, across the room. Sherry glasses front of Galvin and the Bishop. Galvin drinking from his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young woman. In her prime...  deprived of... (searches for a word) ...life... sight... her family...  It's tragic. It's a tragic accident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin has been dreaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...nothing, of course, can begin to  make it right. But we must do what  we can. We must do all that we can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures to the Young Priest, who crosses the room,  extracts a sheet from a file folder, and places it before Galvin, who is sitting as if in a dream. The Bishop waits beat, not wanting to interrupt Galvin's reverie, then cat his eye and gestures down at the paper. Galvin glances do

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sheet: "I, Frank P. Galvin, duly appointed conservato for Deborah Ann Kaye, in consideration of Two Hundred Ten Thousand Dollars ($210,000.00) paid in hand to me this da by St. Catherine Laboure Hospital do hereby release from and all claims..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin and the Bishop as before. Galvin finishes reading, looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. We must try to make it right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Galvin nods. Beat. Bishop nods discreetly to the Yo Priest who extracts Mount Blanc fountain pen from his poc holds it out to Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a generous offer, Mr. Galvin... (beat) ...nothing can make the woman well...  but we try to compensate... to make  a gesture...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you settle on the amount?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought it was just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You thought it was just.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it struck me how neatly  'three' went into the amount. Two  Hundred Ten Thousand. That would  mean I keep seventy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was our insurance company's  recommendation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It would be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing that we can do can make that  woman well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And no one will know the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That that poor girl put her trust in  the hands of two men who took her  life, she's in a coma, her life is  gone. She has no family, she has no  home, she's tied to a machine, she  has no friends -- and the people who  should care for her: her Doctors,  and you, and me, have been bought  off to look the other way. We have  been paid to look the other way. I  came in here to take your money. (beat) I brought snapshots to show you. So  I could get your money. (to Young Priest,  waving away document) I can't take it. If I take it. If I  take that money I'm lost. I'm just  going to be a rich ambulance chaser. (beat; pleading for  understanding) I can't do it. I can't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we may discuss money, Mr. Galvin.  How is your law practice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not too good. I've only got one  client.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, determined, coming down a corridor in the Courtho opens a door. CAMERA FOLLOWS him IN. The Lawyers Room. Ten or twelve AMBULANCE CHASERS waiting for clients. They all look up as he enters, then return to their reading,  phones, card games. CAMERA FOLLOWS him TO the corner of t room where MICKEY MORRISSEY is playing Gin with a CRONY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dragging him up) Come on. Let's get a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs, to partner) Don't touch anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin leads Mickey out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey and Galvin silhouetted against a window at the end the dark corridor, arguing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enraged) Are you out of your mind...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm going to need your help...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need my help...? You need a  goddamn keeper... are you telling me  that you turned down two-hundred-ten  grand? (beat) Huh...? Are you nuts? Eh? Are you  nuts. What are you going to do, bring  her back to life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to help her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do what...? To do what, for  chrissake...? To help her to do what?  She's dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They killed her. And they're trying  to buy it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the point, you stupid fuck.  Let them buy it. We let them buy the  case. That's what I took it for. You  let this drop -- we'll go up to New  Hampshire, kill some fuckin' deer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mick. Mick. Mick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You -- Listen: you said to me, 'if  not now, when...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I said but not now. You  won it. Franky. You won it. When  they give you the money, that means  that you won. We don't want to go to  court -- is this getting to you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know who the attorney is for the Archdiocese, Eddie  Concannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he's a good man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...he's a good man...? He's the Prince  of Fuckin' Darkness... he'll have  people in there testifying that the  broad is well -- they saw her Tuesday  on a surfboard at Hyannis... don't  fuck with this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I have to stand up for her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank, but not now. Frank. You're  trying to wipe out some old business.  But not now. I understand. But you  go call 'em back. You call the Bishop  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to try this case. I have to  do it, Mick. I've got to stand up  for that girl. I need your help. (beat) Mick, will you help me...? (beat) Will you help me...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young ATTORNEY in shirt-sleeves and vest racing through huge, ultra-modern, ultra-successful legal office. The of is near empty. A couple of secretaries are at their desks couple of lawyers in their cubicles. The CAMERA FOLLOWS t Attorney tearing through the corridors of the office, up spiral staircase, through yet more office space, into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a conference room. Mahogany, tinted glass, a panoramic view of Boston. Twenty-five attorneys, male and female, m young, gaze at the young Attorney as he enters the room. stops running. He approaches the front of the room  tentatively. Standing at the blackboard in front of the  conference room is EDWARD CONCANNON. Senior partner of th firm, late fifties, imposing, he radiates success. As the young Attorney approaches Concannon he is stopped with a  gesture. Concannon addresses the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Anybody ever hear, 'For want of a  shoe a horse was lost?' Who's going  on vacation tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young MAN raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Friedman. St. Barts. is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to secretary taking  notes at the side of  the room) Send Mrs. Friedman a dozen roses  tomorrow morning please, Sal. I tell  you what, send her a sunlamp. (smiles, there is  laughter from the  room; to Friedman,  sympathetic) I'm sorry, but you'll have to stay.  No vacations till this thing is  cleared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon motions to the young Attorney who has run in. T young Attorney goes to Concannon and hands him a box of c Concannon takes a piece and writes on the blackboard "Jan 12th." He underlines it heavily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our court date is January twelfth.  You're all acquainted with this case.  It's been scheduled for eighteen  months. We have the attorney for the  Plaintiff, Frank Galvin -- and I  trust you are all familiar with his  record -- and we have been expecting  him to call us to negotiate. As he  did not, and five days before we're  supposed to go to court we made him  a rather generous offer, which he  refused. Five days before the trial.  What does this mean? I want to find  out. (writes on the  blackboard, "1)  Research") (writes "2) Homework") Acquaint yourselves again with the  depositions. Don't rely on the fact  that we did it last year. Do it again.  We're going to review them here, and  you do it at home. You each have a  full file. Know the deps, and I want  you all to be here when we work with  the defendants... when is that,  Billy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young Attorney responds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuesday evening, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon writes on blackboard "3) Public Awareness."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want an article in the Globe As  Soon As Possible, 'St. Cat's...  Neighborhood Giant serving the  community' etc. We've got it in the  files. I want something in Monday's  Herald: 'Our Gallant Doctors,'  something... Be inventive, I want  television... (nods toward one of  the young lawyers) ...talk to our man at GBH. And to  belabor the obvious for a moment... (beat) Our clients are: the Archdiocese of  Boston; St. Catherine Laboure  Hospital, and Drs. Marx and Towler,  two of the most respected men in  their profession. The thrust of this  defense will be to answer in court,  in the press and in the public mind --  to answer the accusation of negligence  this completely: not only that we  win the case, but that we win the  case so that it's seen that the attack  on these men and this institution  was a rank obscenity. (beat) All right. Let's get the cobwebs  off. Billy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young Lawyer stands as Concannon sits, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please turn to your Page Four.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the lawyers in the office turn in their files to that page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to start with a review  of the depositions of the Operating  Room Team: the nurse-anesthetist,  the scrub-nurse, the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin and Mickey at a library table piled with books. A  dingy, dusty law library. They are smoking, speak in  undertones, referring to the yellow legal pads in front o them. Rehashing material.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who have we got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got her sister. Testifies she  had a meal one hour before she was  admitted to the hospital. This is  the point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the admittance form says  patient ate nine hours prior to  admittance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admittance form is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. You can't prove it.  Sister's testimony is no good. Jury  knows we win she gets the cash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got my Dr. Gruber, says her  heart condition means they gave her  the wrong anesthetic anyway, plus  she came in complaining of stomach  pains...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conceding) ...Gruber's not bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not bad...? This guy's Dr. Kildare,  the jury's going to love him, Mick...  And you calm down, all right? Their  guy, Towler's, the author of the  book, (hunts for book on  desk, holds it up;  reads) 'Methodology and Practice,  Anesthesiology.' (rummages through a  pile of papers on  the desk) ...and they got depositions from the  nurses, everybody in the operating  room, the scrub-nurse... 'All these  guys are God. I saw them walk on  water...' (checking a list) They had an obstetrical nurse in  there. We got a deposition from the  obstetrical nurse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking list) No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from pad) 'Mary Rooney, forty-nine. Lives in  Arlington, still working at the  hospital.' Can you get out tomorrow?  How come she isn't speaking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay now. Cases: Smith versus State  of Michigan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brindisi versus Electric Boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got a good memory, Franky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a good teacher. McLean versus  Urban Transport...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin and Mickey entering the bar, walk over to the bar. Galvin sees something O.S. Call to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy? Bushmills. (turns to Mickey,  whispers) Lookit, do me a favor. I'll buy you  a drink tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? And what are you going to do  tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to get laid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin motions with his head down at the end of the bar. ANGLE - P.O.V. The Woman from last night, sitting in her same place at t end of the bar. Mickey looks at her. Shrugs. Gets up off  stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave your best work in the  sheets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He salutes, walks off. Galvin takes his drink and moves down to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you find an apartment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still looking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I changed my life today. What did  you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I changed my room at the Hotel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV didn't work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Hotel are you staying at?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are you? A cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My ex-husband was a lawyer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really. How wonderful for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It was, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, actually it was. Then why'd you  call it off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says I'm the one that called it  off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A brick house says you divorced him.  I'll put you on your honor. Bet you  a hundred dollars against you join  me for dinner. And I'll take your  word for it. Now you tell me the  truth. Because you cannot lie to me.  What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name's Frank. And furthermore,  you came back to see me tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if it wasn't you that I came  back to see?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just got lucky. (gets up off stool) D'you eat yet? Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up from the stool and starts following him in sp of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you are one beautiful woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin and Laura are in a booth. The remains of a dinner drinks around them. They are both smoking cigarettes, int on each other. Both a little drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The weak, the weak have got to have  somebody to fight for them. Isn't  that the truth? You want another  drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin motions "another round" to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy! (beat) That's why the court exists. The  court doesn't exist to give them  justice, eh? But to give them a chance  at justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And are they going to get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They might. Yes. That's the point...  is that they might... you see, the  jury wants to believe. They're all  cynics, sure, because they want to  believe. I have to go in there  tomorrow to find twelve people to  hear this case. I'm going to see a  hundred people and pick twelve. And  every one of them it's written on  their face, 'This is a sham. There  is no justice...' but in their heart  they're saying, 'Maybe... maybe...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Maybe I can do something right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And is that what you're going to do? (a beat) Is that what you're going to do...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm going to try to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bedroom, dark, sound of people moving, the bedside li is flicked on. We SEE Galvin in shirt-sleeves, holding a  whiskey glass a little unsettled, turning on the light, L with a glass, also a bit unsteady, standing beside him. Both awkward. He looks at her, turns back to the bed, tur down the bed, sees the silver-framed picture of his wife, looks back at Laura, starts to take the picture to turn i down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts taking off her blouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A half-full old-fashioned glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin sitting at the fairly well-equipped bar, still. He looks out of the window at a building across the street.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The courthouse across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin glances at bar clock. ANGLE - P.O.V. The clock reads 10:12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin downs his drink, picks his briefcase off of the ba and starts for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE SWEENEY, a florid man in his sixties, sitting in  shirtsleeves eating bacon and eggs off of a hotel service a tray, talking conspiratorially with Ed Concannon, who i drinking coffee, seated across the desk. They are obvious old friends. The sound of a door opening. They turn their heads to the door. ANGLE - P.O.V. Galvin standing in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're late, Mr. Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He enters the room. CAMERA FOLLOWS him as he sits next to Concannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was held up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon smiles and extends his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed Concannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Frank Galvin. We've met before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the Judge starts to speak Galvin cannot help looking a Concannon out of the corner of his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do some business.

dialogues.speaker: P.O.V. GALVIN
dialogues.text: Concannon, brisk, expensive-looking, tanned, huge gold wa custom-made suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They tell me that no bargain ever  was completed other than quickly  when both parties really cared to  make a deal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon feels Galvin's eye on him, half-turns, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, have you boys tried to resolve  your little difficulty because that  certainly would save the Commonwealth  a lot of time and bother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a complicated case, your  Honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure it is, Frank: and let me  tell you something. If we find it so  complex, how in the hell you think  you're going to make a jury understand  it? (smiles at Galvin) See my point? Let's talk a minute.  Frank: what will you and your client  take right now this very minute to  walk out of here and let this damn  thing drop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My client can't walk, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know full well she can't, Frank.  You see the Padre on your way out  and he'll punch your ticket. You  follow me? I'm trying to help you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, Bishop Brophy and the  Archdiocese have offered plaintiff  two hundred and ten thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My doctors didn't want a settlement  at any price. They wanted this cleared  up in court. They want their  vindication. I agree with them. But  for today the offer stands. Before  we begin the publicity of a trial.  For today only. (beat) When I walk out that door the offer  is withdrawn. (turns to Galvin) As long as you understand that. (beat) It's got to be that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are going to try the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Galvin fumbles for a cigarette. The three sit in  silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) That's it...? (beat) Come on, guys... life is too short... (beat) You tell me if you're playing  'chicken,' or you mean it. (beat; turns to Galvin) Frank: I don't think I'm talking out  of school, but I just heard someone  offer you two hundred grand... and  that's a lot of money... and if I  may say, you haven't got the best of  records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...things change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that's true. Sometimes they change,  sometimes they don't. Now, I remember  back to when you were disbarred...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't disbarred, they dropped the  pro...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it seems to me, a fella's trying  to come back, he'd take this  settlement, and get a record for  himself. (beat) I myself would take it and run like  a thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge turns, unbelieving that Galvin has patronized a insulted him. He controls himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hm. (beat; checking book) We have the date set? Next Thursday.  Good. (smiles) See you boys in court.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: A legal document. LIST OF PROSPECTIVE JURORS. DEBORAH ANN KAYE versus ST. CATHERINE LABOURE HOSPITAL, Et. Al.: Mr.  Arthur Abrams, Machinist, 58; Mrs. Joann Chepek, Housewif 42; Mr. Roger Crawford, Chemist, 59, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, seated at the conference table intent on the form front of him. He crosses out something with a pen. Galvin takes the form, rises, walks across the room, walks by th defense table with Concannon and an Aide at it. Approache the Jury Box, which has several prospective JURORS in it. He is very nervous. He addresses a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Abraham...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abrams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abrams. Yes. How are you today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (beat) You ever been inside a hospital?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. How did they treat you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin has flop sweat, Abrams is becoming intractable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey standing by the door to the courtroom, looking thr the glass panel, a newspaper under his arm, smoking. Galv comes out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Been a long time, huh...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm getting it back. Don't worry  about me, Mick. I'm fine. D'you find  the obstetric nurse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Rooney. She won't talk to me. I  tried her at the hospital. I'm going  to try her back at home. Read this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Galvin the newspaper. Galvin takes it, reads. ANGLE - P.O.V. The newspaper, folded to Page Two. A full-page photo of  smiling doctors clustered around an operating table. Huge caption: "International Honors to St. Catherine Laboure  Hospital. The faculte Internationale de la Chirurgerie to announced St. Catherine's as this year's recipient of the coveted Medaillon de la Sante..." etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin reading. Looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what...? The best is yet to come.  Check the TV Guide. They got our Dr.  Towler on a panel on GBH on Friday:  'The Healing Hand. The Experts Speak.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They still have to take it to a jury.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks back at his form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What I'm saying, they're getting  some help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looks annoyed) So what do you want me to do?  Concannon's going to try the case  his way, I'm going to try it mine.  You want me to go wee wee wee all  the time because he's got some flack,  got stories in the newspaper. I'm  going to win this case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking across the Courthouse corridor. Mickey veers off and stops at a Cigar Stand. To the STAND OPERATOR:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John: gimme a cuesta-ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit, what's today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today is Tuesday. What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go see Gruber. (to Cigar Stand  Operator) What's the best cigars you have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give 'em a box of Macanudos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey: I'm supposed to meet somebody  at O'Rourke's, I can't make it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are, Franky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (takes box) Thanks. Can you go over and meet  her...? Tell her I'll stop by when  I'm through... Laura Fischer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Who is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's thirty-three bucks. Can you  believe that...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah. Your broad from last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin pays the Cigar Stand Operator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Franky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell her that I'll meet her there,  okay? See you tomorrow in the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're doing fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them crossing the lobby. Dick Doneghy, looking around the lobby, spies them, start across, and accosts Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said you're gonna call me up.  You didn't call me up. Who do you  think you are? (pushes Galvin into a  wall; advances; pushes  him again) Who do you think you are...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold on a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to have you disbarred. I'm  going to have your ticket. You know  what you did? Do you know what you  did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pushes Galvin again. Galvin waves Mickey off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ruined my life, Mister... Me and  my wife... and I am going to ruin  yours... (pushes Galvin again) You don't have to go out there to  see that girl. We been going four  years. (beat) Four years... my wife's been crying  herself to sleep what they, what,  what they did to her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to you I wouldn't have turned  the offer down unless I thought that  I could win the case...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you thought!? What you thought...  I'm a workingman, I'm trying to get  my wife out of town, we hired you,  we're paying you, I got to find out  from the other side they offered two  hundred...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to win this case... Mist...  Mr. Doneghy... I'm going to the Jury  with a solid case, a famous doctor  as an expert witness, and I'm going  to win eight hundred thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys, you guys, you're all the  same. The Doctors at the hospital,  you... it's 'What I'm going to do  for you'; but you screw up it's 'We  did the best that we could. I'm  dreadfully sorry...' And people like  me live with your mistakes the rest  of our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods sadly to himself. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I could accept the offer right  now, I would. (beat) They took it back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. (starts to walk away  from Galvin; stops) I went to the Bar Association. They  tell me you're going to be disbarred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura is sitting in the same place at the bar. Mickey com up to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franky can't make it. He had an  appointment he forgot, he's going to  see you later. I'm Mickey Morrissey,  we're supposed to get to know each  other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'm I doing so far?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So far you're great. You got a  cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura opens her purse, starts hunting for a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you drinking? (hands him cigarettes,  smiles, calls the  Bartender) Jimmy...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin walks up to a door marked Doctors Only. He opens h briefcase, takes out the box of Macanudo Cigars, smiles t himself, walks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin enters, looks around, it is empty. He looks at the clock, takes out his appointment book, turns to appropria page. ANGLE - P.O.V. The book, written very large: "Dr. Gruber. 7:00 P.M.  Hospital."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin standing, he waits a beat. Starts out of locker ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FOLLOWS him TO Nurses' Station. He speaks to the N behind the desk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gruber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gruber's not here today, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glances down, checks a sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. He hasn't been in all day...  He's not on the chart...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin walking in the snow. Stops outside of a very lovel brownstone with a small brass plaque. The plaque: Dr. Dav C. Gruber. M.D. P.C.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin looking in through the window of the dark, deserte ground-floor office. He knocks on the door. Nothing. He k again. Nothing. He stands unbelieving. EXT. GRUBER'S HOUSE & STREET - NIGHT Galvin getting out of a taxi, rushing up the steps of a  brownstone. Peeps through the window on the side of the h Dark. He grabs the brass knocker. Pounds. Nothing, he pou again. Nothing. He is beaten. He is without resource. He  starts vacantly down the stairs. The door behind him is  opened. He turns. ANGLE - P.O.V. A middle-aged black WOMAN in livery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin in the steps speaking with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gruber.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Gruber's not in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had an appointment at his office,  I think I must have got it wrong. We  had a meeting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hesitates. She has been instructed not to say. Galvin starts up the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... please. My wife... my wife's  prescription has run out. If I can  call him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Halpern's taking all his...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, no. I have to talk to him.  If I can only call him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) He's... you can't reach him, Sir.  He's in the, on some island in the  Caribbean, they don't have a phone. (beat) He'll be back in a week... (beat) If you'd like Dr. Halpern's number...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin turns away from the door. He is still clutching th box of cigars unconsciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey and Laura. Positions unchanged, at the bar. Somewh progressed toward a convivial drunkenness

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stearns, Harrington, you know who  that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge law firm. Okay? They put him  in the firm, he's married,  everything's superb. Franky, he's  starting to talk like he comes from  Dorsetshire, some fuckin' place,  'You must drop by with Pat and me...'  Okay...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and he's making a billion dollars  every minute working for Stearns,  Harrington, and he bought a dog, and  everything is rosy. (beat) Then Mr. Stearns, he tried to fix a  case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Big Boy did...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That Frank was working on. Yeah. He  thought Franky needed some help, so  they bribed a juror. So Franky finds  out. He comes to me in tears. He  thinks that anybody who knows what a  'spinnaker' is got to be a saint. I  told him 'Franky, wake up. These  people are sharks. What do you think  they got so rich from? Doing good?'  He can't be comforted. He tells the  boys at Stearns and Harrington they've  disappointed him, he's going to the  Judge to rat them out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before he can get there here comes  this Federal Marshal, and Franky's  indicted for Jury tampering, they  throw him in jail, he's gonna be  disbarred, his life is over. (beat) Jimmy, gimme another drink. (to Laura) How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jimmy) Me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Now, so he's in jail. He,  finally, he gets to see the light,  he calls up Harrington, he says he  thinks he made a mistake. As if by  magic, charges against him are  dropped, he's released from jail. (beat) P.S. He's fired from the firm, his  wife divorces him, he turns to drink  and mopes around three and a half  years. (beat) You like that story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him. HOLD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow falling. Galvin standing outside, having just rung t bell. The door is opened by a gangly teen-age boy. CAMERA FOLLOWS Galvin into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...the hall of the house. The boy motions toward a closed sliding door and then goes into the living room opposite. Galvin hangs up his coat on the hall coat rack, we hear t boy resume the practice of a passage of Chopin on the pia Galvin knocks on the sliding door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin opens the door and goes into the Judge's darkened  study. The Judge is watching a basketball game on TV, dri a beer. CAMERA FOLLOWS Galvin into the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for seeing me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's perfectly all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge turns down the volume of the game, but keeps watchi it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need an extension for my case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should have taken their offer.  Especially if you were unprepared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a witness disappear on me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That happens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could subpoena him if I had a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a week. This case never  should have come to trial. You know  better. You're Mr. Independent. You  want to be independent? Be independent  now. I've got no sympathy for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Judge leans forward, turns up the volume on the game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT of cars whooshing in the snow past a lonely str corner. A MAN at an open telephone stand. The sound of th telephone on the far end ringing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin at the stand, shivering in the cold, talking on th phone. An open note pad in his bare hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continental Casualty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Alito, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Business hours are over, Sir. This  is the switch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to reach him. This is an  emergency. Could you give me his  home number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Sir, we're not allowed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Would you, would you call him up.  I'll give you my number, and ask  him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't guarantee that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand. Thank you, my name is  Galvin. I'll be at the following  number in a half an hour. It's urgent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin is sitting at his desk, a stack of files piled on desk, he is sorting through them looking for something. T phone rings, he snatches it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello. Yes. Thank you for calling.  Frank Galvin... I'm representing  Deborah Ann Kaye...? I'd like to  discuss your firm's offer of the two  hundred th... In the sense that I  feel that we'd like to accept it. (beat) Well, it's rather a shock to me,  too; but it's my client's wishes...  She's changed her mind as of this  evening... I must say that I tried  to dissuade her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wipes his sweating forehead, he hears the sound of his office door opening, he looks up. ANGLE - P.O.V. Mickey opening the front door to the office, carrying an  armful of lawbooks, and a couple of files, he turns on th lights in the anteroom, and we SEE that he is surprised t see Galvin in the office.

dialogues.speaker: GALVIN
dialogues.text: On the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Well, she, on the eve of the  case... You understand... I think  quite frankly she's come down with  nerves and she'd like...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Mickey comes tentatively into the room and sits a the desk across from Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When was that arrived at...? (beat) I, I know what Mr. Concannon said,  but... I... Well, I think you're  making a mistake... I think that you  should reconsider; why don't you  check with your principals, and I'll  call you in the... (beat) No?... you... uh. All right. No.  That's fine. I understand. Sorry to  bother you at home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up the phone. Sits rock still. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin starts searching through his files again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened, Joey...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't talk now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you meet with Dr. Gruber...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin has found the sheet he is looking for, he extracts from the file. ANGLE - P.O.V. The sheet of yellowing paper. Headed "DEBORAH ANN KAYE Po Drs. to testify: Contact: Dr. Lucien Thompson, Mineola Lo Island; Dr. Duane Litchey..." He turns to second sheet. It is a letter-headed sheet, "Lucien Thompson, M.D." "Dea Mr. Galvin, after studying the case material on Deborah A Kaye, I would be glad..." Galvin turns back to first shee underlines THOMPSON in red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin dialing phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon got to my witness. (beat; to himself) I can't breathe in here... (into phone) Hello Doctor...? (checks sheet) Dr. Thompson. This is Joseph Galvin,  attorney for a Deborah Ann Kaye, we  had some correspondence some time  ago...? That's right. I'm sorry that  we never got back, the case was  postponed, and I've had a changeover  in staff... I'm sorry to call you so  late...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey, looking pityingly at Galvin. Mickey sees the box Macanudo Cigars on the desk, picks them up, starts to ope them -- throws them across the room in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but we have had a change of  strategy, and we were wondering, I  know this is short notice, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin in pants and shirt carrying a drink, distraught,  frightened. Standing in the doorway of his sitting room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
