dialogues.text: Laura in slacks and sweater coming out of the kitchen wit her drink. She sits at worktable on which are Galvin's  briefcase, files, etc. Galvin and Laura. He is biting his nails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like me to leave...? (beat) Is this a bad time -- ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted) What...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a bad time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, we... No... we just had a small  reversal in the case... (beat) I have some, uh... I have some work  to do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They, uh, they got to my witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and is that serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, suddenly focuses, starts for worktable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to go...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, I'm just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops, rubs his face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you get some rest?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't work if you can't think.  You get in bed. It's all right. I'll  stay here with you. It's all right.  Come on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to stay here...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm only going to rest a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Same room, Laura, dressed in Galvin's bathrobe, sitting i the easy chair next to his worktable, smoking a cigarette reading an old hard-cover novel. She looks up across the  room. ANGLE - P.O.V. The door to the bedroom, closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura sighs, takes a drag. Puts the book down on her lap. Sits, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Witness stand. DR. TOWLER, a distinguished man in his fif sitting on the stand. Concannon o.s. The doctor is ill-at ease; smiles nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your name, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Robert Towler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were Deborah Ann Kaye's doctor...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, actually, she was referred to  me. She was Dr. Hagman's patient...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't equivocate. Be positive. Just  tell the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The conference room. WIDE. Concannon's young lawyers taki notes as Concannon rehearses Dr. Towler, a Sony VTR being operated by one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever the 'truth' is, let's hear  that. You were her doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was her doctor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the anesthesiologist at her  delivery May twelfth, nineteen  seventy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I was one of a group of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Answer affirmatively. Simply. Keep  those answers to three words. You  weren't 'part of a group,' you were  her anesthesiologist. Isn't that  right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were there to help Dr. Marx  deliver her baby. Were you not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon starts to stroll a bit around the conference ro in back of the assembled assistants, by the large windows which offer a panoramic view of Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything special about the case?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young lawyer (BILLY), Concannon's right-hand assistan raises his hand to get Concannon's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dr. Towler,  correcting him) When 'Debby'... (to Young Lawyer) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Lawyer nods, makes a notation in his pad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. When Debby...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (switching his tack) Dr. Towler, who was in the operating  room with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Nevins, nurse-anesthetist; Dr.  Marx, of course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods toward Dr. Marx who is in the audience, who nods  back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Rooney, the obstetrical nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did these people do when her  heart stopped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went to Code Blue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Code Blue,' what does that mean...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a common medical expression,  it's a crash program to restore the  heartbeat. Dr. Marx cut an airway in  her trachea, to get her oxygen, her  and the baby... Ms. Nevins...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why wasn't she getting oxygen...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, many reasons, actually...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd aspirated vomitus into her  mask...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She THREW UP IN HER MASK. Let's cut  the bullshit. Say it: She THREW UP  IN HER MASK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She threw up in her mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon nods to the Young Lawyer, who is conscientiousl taking notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and her heart stopped and she  wasn't getting oxygen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what did your team do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...You brought thirty years of medical  experience to bear. Isn't that what  you did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A patient riddled with  complications, questionable  information on her, on her admitting  form...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We did everything we could...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to save her and to save the baby.  Is that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You reached down into death. Now,  isn't that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting overcome) My God, we tried to save her... You  can't know... You can't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (changing tactics;  soothing) Tell us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Dr. Towler sighs. He begins to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People coming out of a just-arrived train.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin watching them, he has a large boutonniere on his l The departing PASSENGERS stream past him. An elderly BLAC MAN passes him by, turns and comes back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Galvin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin turns. He is taken aback. He registers who it must be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Thompson...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was good of you to meet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin cuts him off, takes his bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands. They start...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: into the station. The CAMERA TRACKING BEFORE them. As Gal passes a wastebasket, he deposits his boutonniere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have some errands to run, and then  I thought we'd spend the evening...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding) That's what I'd planned to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to take you to the home to  see the girl...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tapping his briefcase,  referring to his  files) From what I've seen, Mr. Galvin, you  have a very good case...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distracted; thinking  ahead) Yes. Yes. I think so. I hope you'll  be comfortable. I'm putting you up  at my...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I made a reservation at...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...apartment. (stops) No, no. Please. You don't know who  we're dealing with, I, please believe  me, they...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...What difference would...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These people play very rough. They  don't want to lose this case. There's  a lot of pressure they can bring to  bear, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) There's nothing they can do to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin starts them walking again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Sir. Please. Humor me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They have arrived outside at a bank of cabs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll spend the evening together,  I'll put you up, you'll be very  comfortable. Please. (hands Dr. Thompson  an envelope) That's my address. The key is in it. (leans forward to  cabbie) 1225 Commonwealth. (to Dr. Thompson) Treat the place as your own. Please  don't tell anyone you're here, I'll  see you this evening. Thank you, and  thank you for coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts Dr. Thompson's bag into the cab. Dr. Thompson  hesitates, gets into the cab. As the cab pulls out, CAMERA FOLLOWS Galvin TO a bank of  phones outside the station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin at the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Claire, on phone) Mr. Galvin's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me talk to Mickey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Yeah? How's our new witness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you find the obstetric nurse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's workin' the late shift at the  Hospital. She's at home now, I'm  going over there to talk to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the address. I'm gonna go.  We're going to need her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Names on bells. One of them is ROONEY, M. 2D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin standing by the bell. Rings it. Beat. The door is  buzzed, he walks into the vestibule, past mailboxes, up t stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Door opens, MARY ROONEY, a tough-looking woman in nurse w opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin in hall, CAMERA FOLLOWS him TO the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Joe Galvin, I'm representing  Deborah Ann Kaye, case against St.  Catherine Laboure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told the guy I didn't want to talk  to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll just take a minute. Deborah Ann  Kaye. You know what I'm talking about.  The case is going to trial. Our chief  witness is a Dr. David Gruber, you  know who he is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the Assistant Chief of  Anesthesiology, Massachusetts  Commonwealth. He says your doctors,  Towler and Marx, put my girl in the  hospital for life. And we can prove  that. What we don't know is why.  What went on in there? In the O.R.  That's what we'd like to know.  Something went wrong. And you know  what it was. They gave her the wrong  anesthetic. What happened? The phone  rang... someone got distracted...  what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you got your doctor's testimony.  Why do you need me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want someone who was in the O.R.  We're going to win the case, there's  no question of that. It's just a  matter of how big...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got nothing to say to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why aren't you testifying for  their side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She starts to close the door. He stops her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can subpoena you, you know. I can  get you up there on the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ask me what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who put my client in the hospital  for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do it, Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you protecting, then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who says that I'm protecting anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Who is it? The Doctors. What  do you owe them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't owe them a goddamn thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why don't you testify?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You know, you're pushy, fella...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I'm pushy now, wait 'til I  get you on the stand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe you better do that, then. (starts to close door;  stops) You know you guys are all the same.  You don't care who gets hurt. You're  a bunch of whores. You'd do anything  for a dollar. You got no loyalty...  no nothing... you're a bunch of  whores.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young LAWYER on the phone, silent, nodding, taking note He holds up his hand to someone indicating "Almost done.  I'll be right with you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon, in overcoat, about to go out, surrounded by an entourage of secretaries and ASSISTANTS in overcoats, wai on him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon and the Young Attorney. The Young Attorney into phone, "Thank you." He hangs up, starts reading from his  notes to Concannon:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His name is Dr. Lionel Thompson.  City College of New York, Class of  twenty-six. Bachelor of Science; New  York College of Medicine; sixteenth  in a class of twenty-two. Nineteen  seventy-six got a courtesy  appointment, staff of anesthesiology,  Easthampton Hospital for Women. Never  married. Has no honors or degrees of  any weight. Since nineteen seventy- five he's testified in twenty-eight  court cases, twelve malpractice. (smiles, saving his  best 'til last) And he's black.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; stern) I'm going to tell you how you handle  the fact that he's black. You don't  touch it. You don't mention it. You  treat him like anybody else. Neither  better or worse. (smiles) And you get a black lawyer to sit at  our table. Okay...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yessir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. What else do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...get the records of his testimony  in the twelve malpractice cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon nods, meaning "that is correct." He turns, exit with his ENTOURAGE. Over his shoulder:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do it. We'll be at Locke-Obers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Thompson in shirt sleeves, attentive, stands against sideboard. Mickey Morrissey, seated, in an armchair. Grilling him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They gave her the wrong anesthetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting on reciting  a list) Her sister said she ate one hour  prior to admittance... she...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...that's what the sister said. The  chart said she ate nine hours prior  to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...she went in complaining of stomach  cramps. Good doctor would have doubted  the information on the chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that what a good doctor would do?  How old are you, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am seventy-four years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What qualifies you as an expert in  anesthetics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am on the staff of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easthampton Hospital for Women. Excuse  me, what is that, a joke? Let me  tell you something, Doctor, those  men at Catherine Laboure. Men who  are known not only in this city, but  the world, were trying to save a  woman's life. They were there, and  here you are, four years later, read  some hospital report, and say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I made a detailed physical  examination of the patient, Sir,  yesterday evening, I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey drops his belligerent attitude. Turns to someone b him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two men, Galvin standing behind Mickey, smoking. He n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dr. Thompson,  casually) She getting good care over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, yes. It's by no means bad,  I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grilling him again) Then what good would it do to ruin  the reputation of two men, to help a  girl whose life's not going to be  changed in the least? You know what  CODE BLUE means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Code Blue'...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a common medical term.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey half-turns to Galvin, shrugs minutely, meaning, "W in trouble."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hotel room door SEEN from the inside. The handle starts to turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin coming through the door. He looks at Laura, tiredly closes the door behind him, ha up his coat in the closet, moves into the room. As Galvin walks into the room, the CAMERA PRECEDES him and TURNS so that WE NOW SEE them BOTH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to lose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Galvin looks out the window and then looks back t Laura.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think it's my fault?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't there something you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the question. It's over. (beat) Do you think that it's my fault? If  I'd... if I'd... I never should have  taken it. There was no way that I  was going to win.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're talking like a drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's over...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... do you want me to leave?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You do what you want. You want to  leave... You want to go kill yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want me to tell you it's your  fault? It probably is. What are you  going to do about it? (beat) I thought it's not over till the  jury comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me so. Maybe you'd get some  sympathy. You came to the wrong place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what makes you so tough?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I'll tell you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there going to be a later...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not if you don't grow up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I don't 'grow up...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're like a kid, you're coming in  here like it's Saturday night, you  want me to say that you've got a  fever -- you don't have to go to  school...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes head sadly) You, you don't under...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes, I do, Joe. Believe me. You  say you're going to lose. Is it my  fault? Listen! The damned case doesn't  start until tomorrow and already  it's over for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is your wife's picture doing by  the side of your...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that to you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What would you like it to be to me...?  I, I, I can't invest in failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin gets up hurriedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I've...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hurries out of the room. CAMERA FOLLOWS him into the  bathroom, he shuts the door, his chest heaves convulsivel He can't catch his breath... Beat. We hear a knock on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe... (beat) Joe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (screaming) Stop pressuring me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens, Galvin is still trying to catch his breat Laura enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're pressuring yourself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking head, utterly  denying her) No... no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) We've all got to let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin coming down the corridor with Sally Doneghy. They  stop by a door on which the card reads: "PART III. DEBORA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the courtroom. CAMERA FOLLOWS them in. The roo one-quarter filled. Concannon at the defense table with t Defendants, a Black Lawyer, entourage. Galvin stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Sally) I'm going to do the best I can for  you and your sister. I know what it  means to you. Believe me... (beat) It means that much to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns away, walks toward the front of the courtroom,  glances toward the jury box. ANGLE - P.O.V. The Jury, somber, controlled, dignified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin continuing to the defense table, Mickey Morrissey  already seated, studying notes on a yellow legal pad. Gal sits. Mickey looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you holding up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And all we've got is a witch doctor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BAILIFF enters, some SPECTATORS, knowing the routine, start getting to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at it this way: it's refreshing  every time a Doctor takes the stand  he's not a Jew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the Bailiff's "All rise."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The COURTROOM getting to its feet as JUDGE WILLIAM B. HOY enters. The Bailiff, as the Judge sits:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hear ye, hear ye, hear ye, all persons  having anything to do before the  Honorable, the Justices of the  Superior Court now sitting at Boston  within and for the County of Suffolk,  draw near, give your attendance and  you shall be heard. God save the  Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Courtroom is seated. JUDGE motions to the CLERK, who  stands and reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deborah Ann Kaye versus St. Catherine  Laboure, Robert S. Towler, M.D. and  Sheldon F. Marx, M.D.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: GALVIN at Plaintiff's table, looking down at notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is the Plaintiff ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up) Ready, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Defense...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready for the Defense, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Courtroom. P.O.V. JUDGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's begin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin gets to his feet. Walks over to the JURY. Looks at them, appraising. He pauses as before a great effort. Tak a breath. Exhales.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a terrible thing to sit in  judgment. So much rides on it. I  know that you've thought, 'How can I  be pure. How can I be impartial  without being cold. How can I be  merciful and still be just?' And I  know that most of you have said some  sort of prayer this morning to be  helped. To judge correctly. We have  the reputation of two men. Two well  respected doctors and a renowned  hospital before us. And with those  two respected men we have my client,  Deborah Ann Kaye... (beat) ...who was deprived of sight, of  locomotion, hearing, speech, of  everything, in short, which  constitutes her life. (beat) We are going to prove she was deprived  through negligence. (beat) Through the negligence of those  respected men. We will show: One...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lavishly appointed corridor. Alito and BILLY, the YOUNG LAWYER from Concannon's office, walking slowly down the  corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did he go to see Mary Rooney?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's the only nurse who isn't  testifying for the Doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he find?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How good's your intelligence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so what is the rest of his case  aside from Dr. Thompson?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as we know, nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alito nods, they stop outside a large double door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank Mr. Concannon for me. Please  tell him I'll see him at his office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alito knocks on the door. The door is opened by a YOUNG  PRIEST. Alito nods to the Young Lawyer, enters the Bishop's study The door is closed behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The jury box. One JUROR leans over and makes a whispered  comment to another. The SECOND JUROR nods, inclines his h toward the witness box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DR. Thompson on the stand. Composed, waiting. Concannon  consulting his notes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Thompson, just so the Jury knows,  you never treated Deborah Ann Kaye.  Is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is correct. I was engaged to  render an opinion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Engaged to render an opinion. For a  price. Is that correct? You're being  paid to be here today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just as you are, Sir...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you board-certified in  anesthesiology, Doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I am not. It's quite common in  New York State...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...I'm sure it is, but this is  Massachusetts, Doctor. Certified in  Internal Medicine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neurology?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orthopedics?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just an M.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know Dr. Robert Towler...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through, through his book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What book is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meth... Methodology and Technique...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of Anesthesiology?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Methodology and Techniques of  Anesthesiology.' Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am seventy-four years old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Still practice a lot of  medicine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on the staff of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we've heard that. Doctor: you  testify quite a bit against other  physicians? Isn't that right? You,  you're available for that? When you're  paid to be there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. Yes. When a thing is wrong...  as in this case, I am available. I  am seventy-four years old, I am not  board-certified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have been practicing medicine for  forty-six years and I know when an  injustice has been done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you, indeed. I'll bet you do.  Fine. Fine. We'll save the court the  time. We will admit the Doctor as an  'expert witness,' fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in undertone, to  Bailiff) Do we have time this morning to... (glances at watch,  Bailiff nods to him) All right. Mr. Galvin, you want to  continue now, or we can resume with  Dr. Thompson this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rising) Thank you, your Honor, I'll continue.  Dr. Thompson. Did you examine Deborah  Ann Kaye last night at The Northern  Chronic Care Facility?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sustained. Yes. The witness will  confine his testimony to review of  the hospital records.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (patronizing) I believe that's the law... is it  not, Mr. Galvin...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Thompson. From your review of  the hospital records of May twelfth  nineteen seventy-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your opinion, what happened to  Deborah Ann Kaye?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cardiac arrest. During delivery her  heart stopped. When the heart stops  the brain's deprived of oxygen. You  get brain damage. That is why she's  in the state she's in today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Dr. Towler's testified that  they restored the heartbeat within  three or four minutes. In your opinion  is his estimate correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's my opinion it took him much  longer. Nine... ten minutes. There's  too much brain damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge leans over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dr. Thompson) Are you saying that a failure to  restore the heartbeat within nine  minutes in itself constitutes bad  medical practice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He has shouted unconsciously; the whole Courtroom turns t look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Galvin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I may be permitted to question my  own witness in my own way...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd just like to get to the point,  Mr. Galvin. Let's not waste these  people's time. Answer the question,  Mr. Witness. Please. Would a nine  minute lapse in restoring the  heartbeat in and of itself be  negligence?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... in that small context I would  have... I would have to say 'no.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you're saying there's no  negligence, based on my question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... given the limits of your  question, that's correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctors were not negligent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) I... um...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge shrugs, meaning, "Well then what in the hell ar we doing here?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge and Witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Witness starts to step down. Galvin strides over to h and speaks to the Judge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not through with the witness,  your Honor. With all due respect if  you are going to try my case for me  I would appreciate it if you wouldn't  lose it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge stands, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I think that's enough for  this morning. I'll see the Plaintiff's  Counsel in my chambers. Now, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Courtroom rises. The Bailiff is heard, "All rise, cou is adjourned until one o'clock."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, furious, standing against the wall. The Judge com in from his own entrance, shucking his robe. Equally angr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got a letter from the Judge  Advocate's office on you today, fella,  you're on your way out... They should  have kicked you out on that  Lillibridge case. Now this is it  today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm an attorney on trial before the  bar. Representing my client. My  client, do you understand? You open  your mouth and you're losing my case  for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, fella...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, you listen to me. All I wanted  in this case is an even shake. You  rushed me into court in five days...  my star witness disappears, I can't  get a continuance, and I don't give  a damn. I'm going up there and I'm  going to try it. Let the Jury decide.  They told me Sweeney he's a hard- ass, he's a defendant's judge. I  don't care. I said, the hell with  it. The hell with it. I'll take my  chances he'll be fair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin is pacing. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (conciliatory) Galvin, look, many years ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And don't give me this shit, 'I was  a lawyer, too.' 'Cause I know who  you were. You couldn't hack it as a  lawyer. You were Bag Man for the  Boys and you still are. I know who  you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; barely  controlling anger) Are you done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right I'm done. I'm going to  ask for a mistrial and I'm going to  request that you disqualify yourself  from sitting on this case. I'm going  to take a transcript to the State  and ask that they impeach your ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You aren't going to get a mistrial,  boy. We're going back this afternoon,  we're going to try this case to an  end. Now you get out of here before  I call the Bailiff and have you thrown  in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin walking down the corridor, having just come from t Judge's Chambers. Sally Doneghy comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does it mean? (beat) I... I mean we, you have other  tactics...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, yes. Yes. They, they present  their side, and I get the same chance.  To cross-examine... to... to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we going to win? (beat, desperately  needing to trust) We have, you know, other tactics,  though...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods. Beat. Walks off. Galvin turns to the open door the Courtroom, through which the SPECTATORS are reenterin for the afternoon session. Mickey is standing by the door he catches Galvin's eye. They look at each other a moment

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Towler on the witness stand. Concannon walking away f him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin at the Plaintiff's table, hastily scribbling notes he looks up. Gets to his feet, walks over to Dr. Towler i the witness box, the CAMERA MOVES WITH him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Towler...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a record of what happened  in the operating room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's correct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...there are notations every thirty  seconds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...of the procedures...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, the roving nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But those notations stop... (consults notes) ...Four-and-one-half minutes after  Deborah Ann Kaye's...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We, we were rather busy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four-and-one-half minutes after her  heart stopped. (beat) And they resume seven minutes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I've said we had some more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...they start again three minutes  earlier...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had rather more important things  on our mind than taking notes. (beat) We were trying to restore her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened in those three...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...we were trying to restore her  heartbeat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened in those three  minutes...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; controls himself) We'd gone to 'Code Blue,' we were  administering electro...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did it take that long to get her  heartbeat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection, we've...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...to get her heartbeat back...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've touched on this, his own witness  has said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overriding him) ...almost nine minutes... causing  brain damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor...! Your Honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brain damage could have been... it  didn't necessarily take nine minutes,  it could have been caused in two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait, you're saying that  her brain damage could have been  caused by her being deprived of oxygen  for two minutes...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuous) Huh. And why is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she was anemic. (beat) It's right there on her chart. Her  brain was getting less oxygen  anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin is struck dumb. He has just made a terrible error. He looks at Mickey. ANGLE - P.O.V. Mickey looks at Galvin. He shakes his head sadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last of the spectators coming out of the court. Galvi and Dr. Thompson are standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do too well for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you did fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that's not true. (beat) Will you want me to stay on till  Monday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No thank you, Doctor. You go  home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know... sometimes people can  surprise you. Sometimes they have a  great capacity to hear the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... I... yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They shake hands. Dr. Thompson walks off. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you don't want me to stay  on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. Thank you. You go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey walks out of the courtroom arranging papers in his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going back to the office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks off leaving Galvin standing there alone. Laura c out of the courtroom. Tentatively, she looks around. Comes up to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura and Galvin walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it over?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't have a goddamned idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin pacing. Mickey seated. Morose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. What do you do when you don't  have a witness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reciting a catechism;  dispiritedly) You use their witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think we tried that. The case is  over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin continues pacing. He will not hear what was just s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how the fuck... You broke the  first law that they taught you in  law school. You never ask a question  you don't know the answer to. (beat) Frankie, wake up. You got your own  expert witness says there was no  negligence. It's over. Period.  There'll be no other cases...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin turns on him, animal-like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no other cases. This is  the case. (beat) Now you decide... (beat) Are you in or out...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soft, dim lights. Concannon sitting on a couch. He holds red-backed file document. His listener is unseen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know how you feel. I know you don't  believe me, but I do. I'm going to  tell you something I learned when I  was your age. I had prepared a case.  Mr. White asked me, 'How did you  do.' (beat) I said, 'I've done my best.' He said,  'They don't pay you to do your best.  They pay you to win.' (beat) That's what pays for this office. (beat) And that's what pays for the pro  bono work that we do for the poor.  And for the kind of law that you  want to practice. And that's what  pays for your clothes and my whiskey,  and the leisure that we have to sit  back and discuss philosophy. (beat) As we're doing tonight. (beat) We're paid to win the case.

dialogues.speaker: CONCANNON AND LAURA
dialogues.text: Laura sitting across from him, impassive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You finished your marriage. You wanted  to come back and practice law. You  wanted to come back to the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. He hands the red-backed document to her.

dialogues.speaker: THE DOCUMENT
dialogues.text: stamped CONCANNON, BARKER, WHITE. Confidential. Eyes only

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lonely middle-class hotel corridor. HOLD. HOLD. Laura,  tired, enters the corridor from the side and proceeds awa from the CAMERA. The CAMERA FOLLOWS her to her door. She  stops, takes out her key, tiredly opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura opening the door, looks down, sees something, bends down to pick it up. Straightens up.

dialogues.speaker: INSERT
dialogues.text: A hotel envelope, The Hotel Lincoln - Boston, Mass. on th letterhead. Laura's hands open the message, take out a sh of yellow legal paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura closes the door behind her, she does not turn on th light, walks over to a couch by the window, sits down, al the while reading the paper by the outside light. She low the paper to her lap.

dialogues.speaker: INSERT
dialogues.text: The legal sheet. It reads, handwritten: Laura. I'm going to try. When this is over can we go away Joe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey on his feet, pacing. Galvin at a blackboard on whi is written, "Dr. Towler. Dr. Marx. Admitting Form.  Anaesthesia." Etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why doesn't Mary Rooney testify?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you with me... are you awake...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I'm awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rooney's protecting someone. Who is  she protecting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Doctors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's protecting the Doctors she'd  be up there on the stand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listlessly) Read me what she said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin flips through his notes. Reads.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'You guys are a bunch of whores...  uh... loyalty... you don't care who  gets hurt... you don't have any  loyalty...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...one of the other nurses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? They're all testifying. Everybody  who was in the O.R.'s going to take  the stand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Who wasn't in the O.R.?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference can that make...?  All right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts checking the charts. Sighs. "This is useless...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... the admitting nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't do anything. She took the  patient's history and signed the  charts. 'K.C.' (looks in the notes  for what the initials  signify) 'Kathy Costello...'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The 'History'...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (explaining) How old are you, how many children...  when did you last eat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Rooney and another Nurse walking down the corridor  carrying foil-covered dishes of food, chatting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin watching them from behind a corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Nurses come to the corner, Galvin walks past. "Notice Rooney. Stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Rooney. Oh. Listen. (beat) I understand what you are doing. And  I want you to know it's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He nods, starts off in the direction he was going in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin turns, confused. Goes back to her. Warmly,  conciliatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About Kathy Costello. (beat) I understand, and I don't blame you  for shielding her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Mary Rooney motions the other Nurse to go away. She steps closer to Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spoke to her, and everything is  all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, what are you talking about? I  talked to her this morning, and she  said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) She told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (credulous) She did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just saw her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In New York?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw Kat in New York... (beat) ...or is she in town? Is she in  town...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. It occurs to her that she's been duped, as Galvin s off hurriedly down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura. SEEN from the back, walking down the corridor. CAM FOLLOWS her. She stops outside Galvin's door. She turns. We SEE she is carrying a tray of coffee containers. She o door. CAMERA FOLLOWS her INTO the office. Mickey is on th phone in the vestibule, Galvin is on the phone in his off He is just hanging up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura starts distributing coffee. Galvin shouts to Mickey the far room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have anything from the Nurse  Association?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The broad has disappeared...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Hospital...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura goes into Galvin's office with coffee. CAMERA FOLLO her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No records since she quit in '76.  She quit two weeks after the incident.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura hands coffee to Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Mickey) Call the A.M.A. (to Laura) ...I can't talk now. (to Mickey) ...tell them you're Dr. Somebody...  you have to find this nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...yeah... good...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...you need some old forms that she  had... somebody's dying...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin picks up the telephone. Looks down to telephone bo in front of him, open on desk. ANGLE - P.O.V. New York City telephone directory. Two columns of COSTELL Thirty of them crossed off. Galvin on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mrs. Costello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry to bother you so late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura goes over to the couch, sits. Lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Goldberg in Accounting.  We have some money here for you...  This is the Mrs. Costello that used  to be a nurse? (beat) I'm sorry. I think we have our records  mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura sitting on the couch. Tense. Smoking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you related to Kathy Costello,  the R.N.?... I'm sorry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear Mickey on his phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, this is Dr. Dorchester in  Boston. This is an emergency. A nurse  left my employ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura on the couch. Galvin dialing the phone. Mickey HALF SEEN in the next room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...four years ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. This is Mr. Dorchester in  Records. We're looking for Kathy  Costello...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over; in the  other room, shouting) I need a cigarette! (resumes on-the-phone  tone) She left my office four years ago,  we're looking for a chart... (covers phone; again  shouts) I need a cigarette...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura looks around the desk, picks up one then another pa crushes them, empty. She nods to herself, picks up her co off the couch in the anteroom, and starts down the hall. Going through the door, she turns, looks back. ANGLE - P.O.V. Galvin in the inner office, on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I'll hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up. Sees Laura, gives her a half-smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Near the cash register of an all-night diner in the busin district, the deserted streets outside. Laura -- standing next to a wall phone, exhausted. She is handed a cardboar tray with three coffees on it and two packs of Pall Malls and some change by the Proprietor. She takes the change a turns her head to look at the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey asleep on the couch, coffee containers around him, ashtray full of butts. Beat. We hear a telephone being di

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, exhausted, smoking, on the telephone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. This is Ross Williams. I'm  calling from California. I'm sorry.  I know it's late in the East, but  this is an emergency. May I please  speak to Kathy Costello? (beat) I'm sorry. My records must be  confused. This is the family of Kathy  Costello...? Please excuse it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. Reaches for a bottle of whiskey on his desk. Pours a shot into a glass. Downs it. His attention is cau by something across the room. ANGLE - P.O.V. Laura asleep on the couch, covered in Galvin's overcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin looks gratefully at her. He begins dialing the pho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small bundle of mail is pushed through the vertical slo and falls to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interior office. Early morning. Galvin asleep with his he on his desk. Mickey asleep in a chair. Laura asleep on th couch, covered with Galvin's overcoat. Galvin wakes up,  startled by the sound of the mail dropping. He picks up t phone mechanically. He realizes it is morning and he has  been asleep. He replaces phone. He surveys the office. Dead, resigned. He closes the phone book. He reaches in a pack of cigarettes on the desk. It is empty. He roots in ashtray for a long butt. This disgusts him. He rejects it Rubs his eyes. Gets up. Goes to the window, stares out. L back at the scene in his office. It is over. He stands by Laura and looks down at her, he looks at Mic He has let them down. He goes to a cabinet under the lawb and takes out a bottle of whiskey and a water glass. He w into the anteroom. Sighs, sits on the couch near the door Glances at the several letters that have just fallen thro the slot. He pours a half-tumbler full of whiskey, and dr it. He refills the tumbler. He absently picks up the mail and starts mechanically sorting through it. He stops at a official-looking piece. ANGLE - P.O.V. The letter, return address MASSACHUSETTS BAR ASSOCIATION. URGENT. He lethargically opens the letter. On Bar Association  letterhead, it reads: "You are directed to appear on Janu 15th to show cause why you should not be disbarred. You a permitted to be represented by counsel of your choice, an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin reading the letter. He crumbles it and throws it i the wastebasket. He looks at the next letter and skims it into the wastebasket. He looks at the next letter and sto ANGLE - P.O.V. It is a phone bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin hurrying up the steps of the tenement. CAMERA FOLL him into the vestibule. It is Mary Rooney's tenement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops by the mailboxes, bends over to read the names. ANGLE - P.O.V. The mailboxes: Swoboda; Murch; M. Rooney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin straightens, looks around the vestibule, takes hea letter opener from his jacket pocket and pries open the R mailbox. He extracts letters and rifles through them. ANGLE - P.O.V. Mary Rooney's phone bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin in an old-fashioned sit-down phonebooth in a drugs He is dialing the phone, holding the phone bill. The oper answers, he starts dropping change into the slot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The phone bill opened. It reads, "Rooney, Mary A. 263 Chu Street, Arlington, Mass." Various local charges. One call Chicago. One call to Fort Lauderdale. Eight calls to New  York. The calls to New York are circled in pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice over; on phone) Hello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, I'm calling from...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you're selling something, I'm  late for work...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm calling from Professional Nurse  Quarterly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the magazine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Mr. Wallace in Subscriptions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're calling me from...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Miss Costello...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Price...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pardon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We find that your subscription  lapsed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) My subscription lapsed three years  ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's why I'm calling, Miss Price...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Missus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a renew-your-subscription  offer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We get it at work. We get the magazine  at work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, we know that you do. I have it  in my files. That's at the Manhattan  Health Center...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. At Chelsea Childcare. Okay. Look,  call me Monday, hey? I'm late for  work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin scribbles on pad as we hear Kathy hanging up. "Kat Price. Chelsea Childcare."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin hurrying across the lobby. Stops by DO IT YOURSELF SHUTTLE TICKET COUNTER. Takes form, starts to write on it ANGLE - P.O.V. The form "BOSTON - NEW YORK SHUTTLE. SELF SERVICE TICKET. Galvin filling in his name and address in pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura asleep on the couch. Mickey asleep on the other cou The phone is ringing. She wakes up. Looks around. Goes  groggily to phone, answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello? Mr. Gal... where are you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey wakes up, looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going to New York? I... you're  kidding... Because I'm going to New  York. (beat) I just got a call. I have to go sign  papers. About my divorce. I... good.  Frank. We'll meet there. All right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey has woken up. Swings his feet to the floor. Picks a pack of cigarettes. Crushes it. It is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we meet there, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey gets to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Laura) You got a cigarette...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She shrugs, "I don't know..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the Beacon. On Fifty-third  Street... we can spend the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey has gone over to Laura's purse. Opens it, rummagin Comes up with a pack of cigarettes. He sees something in purse. Stops. ANGLE - P.O.V. The open purse. The red-backed legal form. The letterhead reads, "CONCANNON, BARKER, WHITE," stamped huge across it black: "CONFIDENTIAL. EYES ONLY!!!" Mickey takes out the  form, turns page. It reads, "Report on Joseph Galvin," li haunts, habits, and is heavily notated in various types o pen and pencil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (on phone) At around four...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey replacing the form and the cigarettes. He re-close the purse. He turns to her. She has seen nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel the same way, Joe... I'll see  you this afternoon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got any cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two very young children walk across a play area. The door the play area opens and Joe Galvin, in overcoat, comes in He looks around the room, starts to walk across it. CAMERA PANS WITH him to REVEAL a woman, KATHY, who is  comforting a crying child. Galvin walks over to her. Stan a respectful distance away. She sees him watching her, lo up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods, happy to be working with the child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been meaning to come in a long  time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You live in the neighborhood?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. My nephew's going to be  staying with us in a few months, so  I stopped by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four. You're great with these kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She beams, caught unprepared in something that is a great point of pride with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're really... (stops, remembering  something) You, are you the one they told me  was the nurse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gestures back at the  office, vaguely) Mrs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Simmonds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (very serious, correct) I used to be a nurse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a wonderful profession. My  daughter-in-law's a nurse. What did  you do, stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy is lost in thought. This is obviously a very painfu subject for her. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, getting involved in a serious conversation, takes off his overcoat, he is going to stay awhile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you stopped?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is traumatized by the question. The casual conversati has become immediate and painful. She opens her mouth to  speak, then stops, staring at Galvin. He doesn't know wha she is staring at... something on his jacket. He looks do ANGLE - KATHY'S P.O.V. The shuttle ticket, BOSTON - NEW YORK, stuck in the lapel pocket of Galvin's suitcoat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy and Galvin. She realizes why he is there. She start to cry quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat; gently dropping  his pretense) Will you help me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The restaurant fairly deserted after the lunch crowd. Emp tables -- crisp linen, Laura alone at a table, watching t door, an untouched cup of coffee in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorman opens the door of a cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey Morrissey standing in an alcove under the marquee, looking out at the street. ANGLE - P.O.V. The street. Pedestrians. Joe Galvin comes walking hurried smiling, down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mickey starting down the steps, intercepts Galvin. Galvin looks up, surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got to talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is moving Galvin off down the sidewalk, away from the  Hotel. CAMERA STAYS STILL, and their voices get fainter a they move away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing in New York...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we'll get a cup of coffee...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue walking. We cannot hear them. Galvin is bec agitated. He stops Mickey, stands there, Mickey very sad, Galvin incredulous, talking to him. Mickey nods. Galvin starts hurriedly back down the street toward the H

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT of Laura seated at a table alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin at the entrance to the restaurant looking at her. walks over to her slowly.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: Laura, looks up, sees him, smiles. Her smile fades, she s that he knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura getting up from the table. We SEE her back, and Gal approaching. We SEE her shoulders droop, beaten. He draws closer. Galvin comes up to her, his face a mask of pain a confusion. She sighs, starts to speak. Stops. Beat. They  look at each other -- he starts to speak, cannot. He knoc her to the floor, she upsets the table. A large man at th next table starts to restrain Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as if in shock) It's all right... it's all right...  it's all right... it's all right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin and Mickey seated next to him, flying home in sile Mickey smoking a cigarette. Galvin stone-faced, beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I talked to Johnnie White at the Bar  Association. (beat) The broad used to work for one of  Concannon's partners in New York  awhile ago. (beat; lamely) She wanted to move to Boston. (beat) How badly did she hurt us, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got a mistrial, you know. Joe --  did you hear what I said...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want a mistrial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doorway to his study. A basketball game dimly SEEN in the half-light. Mickey, o.s.:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not here. (pause) Yeah. I don't know when. (pause) All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound of him hanging up a telephone. He enters the frame  carrying a bottle of booze, goes through door into study.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Knicks are pressing hard... (etc.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits on a sofa opposite the television. Watches the ga a beat. Opens the fresh bottle of whiskey and pours a lar shot into the almost-empty glass in front of him. Looks t his left. Reaches behind him to some glasses on a shelf,  takes one down, pours drink into the new glass, leans to left, CAMERA MOVES WITH him, and we SEE Galvin sitting in deep leather armchair, staring. Mickey offers him the dri Galvin becomes aware of him, shakes his head "no." Beat. Mickey moves back into his seat, they both stare at the  television.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Half full of spectators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin gets up from Plaintiff's table, takes up a large b as Dr. Towler takes the stands. He reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Towler; page 406,  'Contraindications to general  anesthetic. Ideally a patient should  refrain from taking nourishment up  to nine hours prior to induction of  general anesthetic.' Does that sound  familiar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I wrote it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin shows the book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Practice and Methodology in  Anaesthesia.' General textbook on  the subject. Is that correct?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I. Yes. It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you wrote that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading) ...Page 414, 'If a patient has taken  nourishment within one hour prior to  inducement, general anesthetic should  be avoided at all costs because of  the grave risk the patient will  aspirate food particles into his  mask.' Is that what happened to  Deborah Ann Kaye? She aspirated into  her mask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She threw up in her mask, yes. But  she hadn't eaten one hour prior to  admission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she had eaten, say one hour prior  to admission, the inducement of a  general anesthetic... the type you  gave her... would have been  negligent...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negligent. Yes... it would have been  criminal. But that was not the case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin signals he is done. The Judge signals Dr. Towler t leave the stand, which he does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Concannon...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing further, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Galvin, rebuttal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Bailiff) Katherine Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bailiff calls out her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine Price...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy at the back of the court, coming down the aisle. As she passes the Defendant's table, Towler grabs Marx and s whispering frantically. Concannon looks on, ignorant of w is happening. We hear Dr. Towler's "Oh, my God..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin surveys the courtroom, Kathy crosses in front of h takes the stand, we hear the Bailiff administering the fo as we WATCH Galvin turn and look at the Jurors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State your name please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Katherine Lynn Price.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you swear that the evidence you  are about to give will be the truth,  the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bailiff swearing in Kathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...whole truth and nothing but the  truth, so help you God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be seated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy sits, the Bailiff retires, Galvin walks over to her

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy Price...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were the Admitting Nurse at St.  Catherine Laboure Hospital on May  twelfth, nineteen seventy-six, the  night Deborah Ann Kaye was admitted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin holds up a form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You signed this form?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks closely at it. Is satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are your initials, 'K.C.'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy Costello. That's my maiden  name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D'you ask the patient when did she  last eat?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She said she had a full meal one  hour before coming to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And did you write the numeral 'one'  down on the record, standing for one  hour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A single hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin walks away from the witness box. He looks at the j He turns to look at the spectators. His thoughts are a mi miles away. Unconsciously he straightens his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin in front of the dead-still courtroom. He breaks hi reverie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Concannon) Your witness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon is on his feet as Galvin walks back to his tabl Concannon walks over to Kathy and begins forcefully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are aware of the penalties for  perjury...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. (beat) It is a crime. A serious crime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would not...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In fact, you've just taken an oath  that you would not commit perjury.  You've just sworn to that. Isn't  that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...sworn before God you would tell  the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. I'd like to ask you something:  four years ago, when you were working  as a nurse, are you aware that Drs.  Towler and Marx based their treatment  of Deborah Ann Kaye on this chart  that you signed...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wasn't that an oath...? These  are your initials here: K.C. When  you signed this chart you took an  oath. No less important than that  which you took today. (beat) Isn't that right? (beat) Isn't that right...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, please, which is correct? You've  sworn today the patient ate one hour  ago. Four years ago you swore she  ate nine hours ago? Which is the  lie. When were you lying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know these doctors could have  settled out of court. They wanted a  trial. They wanted to clear their  names.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you would come here, and on a  slip of memory four years ago, you'd  ruin their lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They lied.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'They lied.' Indeed! When did they  lie? And do you know what a lie is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding chart) You swore on this form that the  patient ate nine hours ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not my handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've just said you signed it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I, yes, I signed it, yes. But  I, I didn't write that figure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't write that figure. And  how is it that you remember that so  clearly after four years?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a paper out  of her purse) Because I kept a copy. I have it  right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks toward Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin nods, meaning, "You did it perfectly."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon, the Judge, Kathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Objection! This is ri... expect us  to accept a photocopy, we have the  original right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll rule on that presently. (beat) Proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon is taken up short. Amazed at the Judge's reacti he pauses an instant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please proceed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon motions to Billy, the young lawyer, who nods in response and starts whispering instructions to his collea at the Defense table, who start leafing through their  lawbooks. Concannon takes up the fight again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...what in the world would induce  you to make a photocopy of some  obscure record and hold it four years?  This is a... why? Why would you do  that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I would need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why, please tell us, would you  think that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After, after the operation, when  that poor girl, she went in a coma.  Dr. Towler called me in. He told me  he had five difficult deliveries in  a row and he was tired, and he never  looked at the admittance form. (beat) And he told me to change the form.  He told me to change the one to a  nine. (beat) Or else, or else, he said... (beat; starts to cry) He said he'd fire me. He said I'd  never work again... Who were these  men...? Who were these men...? I  wanted to be a nurse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is weeping copiously. A beat. She starts to get herse under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No further questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may step down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Kathy starts to get down. She looks to Galvin for  assurance. Galvin nods at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Galvin...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kathy getting down from the stand. The Judge addressing  Galvin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing further, your Honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Concannon...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon is signalled by Billy, the young lawyer at the  Defense table, who is gathering notes from his colleagues who have been researching during Kathy's speech. Concannon walks over to the table and is quickly "talked  through" the notes by Billy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Concannon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon cuts Billy short, meaning, "Yes, I understand, far ahead of you," he takes the notes and returns to the  bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, your Honor.
