We object to  the copy of the admissions form as  incompetent and essentially hearsay  evidence and cite McGee versus State  of Indiana, U.S. 131 point 2 and 216  through 25 of the Uniform Code: 'The  admission of a duplicate document in  preference to an existing original  must presuppose the possibility of  alteration and so must be disallowed.'  And, your Honor, having given the  Plaintiff the leeway we would like  your ruling on this issue now: we  object to the admission of the Xerox  form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...one moment, Mr. Concannon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge nods, meaning, "I am considering..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Judge. He is making some notations on a page in front him. He nods to himself, he has reached a decision. He lo up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The document is disallowed, the jury  will be advised not to consider the  testimony of Kathy Costello regarding  the Xerox form. (explains to them) It's unsubstantiated and we can't  accept a copy in preference to the  original...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, your Honor. Further: Ms.  Costello is a rebuttal witness. As a  'Surprise Witness' she may only serve  to rebut direct testimony. As her  only evidentiary rebuttal was the  admitting form, which has been  disallowed I request that her entire  testimony be disallowed and the jury  advised that they must totally  disregard her appearance here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to uphold that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin getting to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I object, your Honor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overruled...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exception!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noted. Thank you. (to Jury) Miss Costello was a rebuttal witness.  Her sole rebuttal was the document,  which has been disallowed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, silent, fuming, sitting at the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her entire testimony must be stricken  from the record. You shouldn't have  heard it, but you did. Now, that was  my mistake... and you must strike it  from your minds, give it no weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin takes a sheet of legal paper and starts writing on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Legally it's over. Concannon was  brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about Kaitlin Costello.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to tell. It's been  stricken from the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Did you believe her?

dialogues.speaker: FULL COURTROOM -
dialogues.text: All looking slightly to their right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Galvin...?

dialogues.speaker: GALVIN
dialogues.text: In front of the full jury box. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, so much of the time we're  lost. We say, 'Please, God, tell us  what is right. Tell us what's true.  There is no justice. The rich win,  the poor are powerless...' We become  tired of hearing people lie. After a  time we become dead. A little dead.  We start thinking of ourselves as  victims. (pause) And we become victims. (pause) And we become weak... and doubt  ourselves, and doubt our  institutions... and doubt our  beliefs... we say for example, 'The  law is a sham... there is no law...  I was a fool for having believed  there was.' (beat) But today you are the law. You are  the law... And not some book and not  the lawyers, or the marble statues  and the trappings of the court...  all that they are is symbols. (beat) Of our desire to be just... (beat) All that they are, in effect, is a  prayer... (beat) ...a fervent, and a frightened prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my religion we say, 'Act as if  you had faith, and faith will be  given to you.' (beat) If... If we would have faith in  justice, we must only believe in  ourselves. (beat) And act with justice. (beat) And I believe that there is justice  in our hearts. (beat) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stands still a moment, then surveys the still courtroo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Laura in the corridor, watching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jurors filing in from the Jury Room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Concannon, Young Lawyer, Dr. Towler, Dr. Marx at Defense  table. Young Lawyer scribbles a note, passes it to Concannon, wh ignores it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plaintiff's table. Galvin looking at the Jury, Mickey at other end of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you reached a verdict?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have, your Honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jury Box. The Jurors seated, the FOREMAN standing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Honor, we have agreed to hold  for the Plaintiff... but on the size  of the award, are we bound...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are not bound by anything, other  than your good judgment, based on  the evidence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin, totally defeated. Nods his head sadly, as if  commiserating philosophically, with himself. Mickey looks him in grief, with sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we permitted to award an amount  greater than the amount the Plaintiff  asked for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin slowly raises his head, turns and looks at the Jur Mickey begins to smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You are.

dialogues.speaker: MICKEY'S P.O.V.
dialogues.text: The courtroom, commotion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please retire and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin and Mickey standing near a back staircase, cleanin equipment is lying all around. A large, battered garbage  can. Mickey is lighting Galvin's cigarette. Galvin's hand shakes badly. Something draws his attention at the end of the corridor. He turns his head. ANGLE - P.O.V. Laura, standing at the end of the corridor. Tentative, lo pleading silently, she holds a sheet of yellow legal pape in her hand. ANGLE - INSERT - LAURA'S P.O.V.

dialogues.speaker: THE PAPER READS
dialogues.text: 'Laura. I'm going to try. When this is over can we go awa 'Joe' 'Thank you' ANGLE - GALVIN'S P.O.V. Laura holding the paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin and Mickey looking at her. Galvin's face impassive Beat. He turns his back on her. Mickey does likewise. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Galvin) The jury might be out for awhile. (beat; tentatively) You want to run across the street  and get a drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat. Galvin puts his arm around Mickey's shoulder. They  push through the Exit Door, turning up their collars to t cold. Galvin hesitates a moment as Mickey goes through th door. Beat. He looks back longingly. ANGLE - GALVIN'S P.O.V. The deserted corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Galvin standing framed in the doorway. He turns toward th door, his back to the CAMERA, his shoulders slumped. He s for a moment, sighs, straightens up, and walks through th door.
